headline.main: White House and Congress on Verge of Tax Deal

byline.original: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House and Congressional leaders seemed today to be within an eyelash of reaching the tax compromise crucial to a new budget. They have tentatively agreed on a 31 percent top tax rate, up from the current 28 percent. These other elements are more or less locked up: a limit on deductions that could be claimed by people with total incomes above $100,000, a modest rise in the gasoline tax, cuts in Medicare payments, a steep increase in the amount of wages subject to the Medicare payroll tax, luxury taxes on expensive cars, boats, private planes, furs and jewelry, and higher taxes on tobacco products and alcoholic beverages. Real Numbers Not Released
